subject: ACCT
title: Financial Accounting
description: Introduces the basic terminology, concepts, and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Concepts will include revenue and expense recognition, accounts receivable, inventory, long-lived assets, liquidity, and solvency. Explores the income statement, balance sheet, and statement of cash flows, often using reports filed by publicly-traded companies. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: AFAM
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Critical survey of political moments and cultural expressions of African and African descended people since the social, cultural, and political upheavals of the 1970âs. The contours of Black diaspora politics and erotics will be explored. Key discourses, practices, movements, and theorizations of Black public culture will be covered by confronting a range of local sites/events/texts in Africa, the Caribbean, Europe, Latin America, but mostly in the US and UK. These will highlight issues of performance and style; pleasure/joy; representation; gender; sexuality; race; and class. Interdisciplinary assignments are drawn from across various academic and aesthetic disciplines, ethnography, cultural criticism, and everyday life. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: AFAM
title: Multiculturalism and the Order...
description: Is there a link between social identity and crime? What is the relationship among race, gender, and perceptions of criminality? What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime, and criminal justice policy? This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime, and the criminal justice system. Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice. Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: AFST
title: Society and Politics of North...
long_title: Society and Politics of North Africa
description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. Overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and have the option of home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 27-August 1.

subject: AMST
title: Multiculturalism and the Order...
description: Is there a link between social identity and crime? What is the relationship among race, gender, and perceptions of criminality? What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime, and criminal justice policy? This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime, and the criminal justice system. Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice. Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: AMST
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Transnational history and cultural transmission of yoga philosophies, institutions, and practices in the United States. Readings draw on work in anthropology, history, religious studies, psychology, and neuroscience to examine how genealogies of anti-normative modes of embodiment, physical movement, and conceptions of the self are rooted in colonial encounters that haunt the multibillion-dollar yoga industry today. Excerpts from ancient yogic texts such as the Bhagavad Gita and The Yoga Sutras of Patanjali. Mats will be provided for students to practice yogic techniques. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: AMST
title: U.S. Border & Immigration Policy
description: U.S. border and immigration policies at the national, state, and local levels from the colonial period to the present. The historical evolution of border and immigration policy; contemporary debates; the effects of shifting policy on immigrants of varying legal statuses. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: AMST
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Theories of race and performance, the role of bodies in constructions of race, and the perception of race. The performing body as a site of subjectivity, resistance, and interrogation as we look at work from artists who have pushed boundaries of identity, gender, and ethnicity. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: AMST
title: Inequality in America
description: The sociocultural dimensions of inequality in the contemporary United States. Readings draw on work in anthropology, sociology, economics, history, cultural studies, and investigative journalism to examine how neoliberal policies, exacerbated by the Great Recession, impact Americans divided by identity categories such as race, class, gender, and citizenship. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: AMST
title: Film, Video, and American Hist...
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include American films from a broad range of time periods and genres. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ANTH
title: Introduction to Cultural Anthr...
description: An introduction to the central ideas, methods, and debates that make up the anthropological study of human thought and behavior. Survey of dynamic ways of life in many different societies; outline of the ways anthropologists have tried to understand societies. Hands-on ethnographic research provides insight into how cultural anthropologists do what they doâwhat problems they encounter and what tools and techniques they use for research and analysis. Film screenings meet Wednesdays 7-9 pm. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ANTH
title: Introduction to Biological Ant...
description: Introduction to human and primate evolution, primate behavior, and human biology. Topics include a review of principles of evolutionary and population biology, the evolution of primates and people, and current thinking about the evolution of human behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ANTH
title: Forensic Anthropology
description: Hands-on introduction to forensic anthropology, using laboratory training, lectures, and case studies. Introduction to basic skeletal anatomy and to the use of recovered skeletal materials to assess a deceased individual's age, sex, height, ancestry, time of death, bone trauma, and disease. Additional topics include techniques for recovering human skeletal remains, reconstruction of faces, genetic identification, and medicolegal contexts of forensic anthropology. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
long_title: The Genesis and Collapse of Old World Civilizations
description: Cancelled. The archaeology of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley from early agriculture to the earliest cities, states, and empires. Explores how these societies developed and why they collapsed. Earliest epics and contemporary ideologies, including the Bushes in Baghdad, examined in literature and film. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Transnational history and cultural transmission of yoga philosophies, institutions, and practices in the United States. Readings draw on work in anthropology, history, religious studies, psychology, and neuroscience to examine how genealogies of anti-normative modes of embodiment, physical movement, and conceptions of the self are rooted in colonial encounters that haunt the multibillion-dollar yoga industry today. Excerpts from yogic texts such as the Bhagavad Gita and the Yoga Sutras of Patanjali. Mats will be provided for students to practice yogic techniques. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ANTH
title: Cultures and Markets in Asia
description: How markets and capital have shaped and are shaped by recent cultural, political and economic transformations in Asia. Classic and contemporary anthropological approaches to markets, exchange, and money. Modern financial sites like the stock exchange in Shanghai, the Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo, clothing marketplaces in Ho Chi Minh City, and the luxury real estate market in Russian Siberia. How postsocialist transformations, changing gender roles, and rapid urbanization enable economic growth, produce new power relations, and revise cultural meanings of familiar terms like value, labor, and success. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ANTH
title: Southeast Asia in Context
description: Offered in Singapore. This course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities' Global Summer Program. Southeast Asia in Context is a five-week thematically based exploration of Southeast Asia's geographical and cultural diversity, which takes advantage of Singapore's position and character as a microcosm of this diversity. Blending classroom instruction on NUS Kent Ridge campus with hands-on fieldwork in Singapore, Cambodia and Thailand, SEA in Context offers modules on Southeast Asia with anthropological, historical and archaeological concentrations. The core module, SE2222: Southeast Asia in Context provides a broad overview of Southeast Asia from a historical, sociological, and anthropological perspective. Its partner module, SE2880A: Southeast Asia's Cultural Mosaic, will equip students with the analytical tools for the comparative study of society and culture, and features a 10-day field trip to various religious, cultural, and archaeological sites in Cambodia and Thailand. Both modules deploy context-based learning by combining in-class instruction at NUS campus with local and regional hands-on experience of Southeast Asian life. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Singapore, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Yale Credit and 1 NUS Credit. Tuition: TBA. Course dates: June 21 - July 25.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. This course explores the social and political significance of contemporary popular expressive forms from across the African continent, including music, television, fashion, dance, screen media, sport, and visual art. Theoretical and ethnographic readings call into question common stereotypes of African cultural production as either traditional and authentic or elite and borrowed. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. The digital and computational mediation of meaning and human-based significance in relation to machine-based sieving. Readings from classic works in media studies, cybernetics, computer science, semiotics, anthropology, and critical theory. Key topics include: the relation between meaning and information; the relation between interpretation and computation; and the relation between interaction and infrastructure. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ANTH
title: Inequality in America
description: The sociocultural dimensions of inequality in the contemporary United States. Readings draw on work in anthropology, sociology, economics, history, cultural studies, and investigative journalism to examine how neoliberal policies, exacerbated by the Great Recession, impact Americans divided by identity categories such as race, class, gender, and citizenship. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Critical survey of political moments and cultural expressions of African and African descended people since the social, cultural, and political upheavals of the 1970âs. The contours of Black diaspora politics and erotics will be explored. Key discourses, practices, movements, and theorizations of Black public culture will be covered by confronting a range of local sites/events/texts in Africa, the Caribbean, Europe, Latin America, but mostly in the US and UK. These will highlight issues of performance and style; pleasure/joy; representation; gender; sexuality; race; and class. Interdisciplinary assignments are drawn from across various academic and aesthetic disciplines, ethnography, cultural criticism, and everyday life. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ANTH
title: Anthropology of Media
description: The production, circulation, and consumption of media and popular culture in different cultural and national contexts. Exploration of the centrality of mass, digital and social media to life in the 20th and 21st centuries, and the usefulness of anthropology in exploring its analytical and practical significance. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Offered in Tokyo. Animation (anime) and graphic novels (manga) in twentieth-century Japan. Focus on the social and historical context of the production and consumption of manga and anime. Explore gender and sexuality through these media and in Japanese popular culture. Create your own anime or manga short. No knowledge of Japanese required. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Tokyo, costs of room and board in Tokyo, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 1-July 3.

subject: APHY
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: APHY
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ARBC
title: Elementary Modern Standard Ara...
description: Development of a basic knowledge of Modern Standard Arabic through a comprehensive and integrated method emphasizing reading, writing, speaking, comprehension, grammar, and vocabulary acquisition. Credit only on completion of ARBC S120. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ARBC
title: Elementary Modern Standard Ara...
description: Continuation of ARBC S110. Prerequisite: ARBC S110, 110a or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ARBC
title: Intermediate Modern Standard A...
description: Offered in Rabat, Morocco. Intensive review of grammar; readings from contemporary and classical Arab authors with emphasis on serial reading of unvoweled Arabic texts, prose composition, and formal conversation. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with ARBC S140. Credit only after completion of ARBC S140. Prerequisite: ARBC 120 or equivalent. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Course dates: May 30-July 25.

subject: ARBC
title: Intermediate Modern Standard A...
description: Offered in Rabat, Morocco. Continuation of ARBC S130. Intensive review of grammar; readings from contemporary and classical Arab authors with emphasis on serial reading of unvoweled Arabic texts, prose composition, and formal conversation.Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with ARBC S130. Prerequisite: ARBC 130 or equivalent. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Course dates: May 30-July 25.

subject: ARCG
title: Buried Cities: Thera, Pompeii,...
description: Introduction to the art and archaeology of three Mediterranean sites buried by volcanic eruptions, with special attention to new discoveries and interpretations. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ARCG
title: CANCELLED
long_title: The Genesis and Collapse of World Civilizations
description: Cancelled. The archaeology of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley from early agriculture to the earliest cities, states, and empires. Explores how these societies developed and why they collapsed. Earliest epics and contemporary ideologies, including the Bushes in Baghdad, examined in literature and film. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ART
title: Basic Drawing
description: An introduction to drawing, emphasizing pictorial syntax and the articulation of space. Class work is based on observational study. Assigned projects address fundamental technical and conceptual problems suggested by historical and recent artistic practice. No prior drawing experience necessary. Enrollment limited to 20 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,800. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ART
title: Art Production in Metal and Wood
long_title: Art Production in Metal and Wood
description: Various processes and properties that metal and wood offer to the production of sculptural works of art. Techniques in metal and wood fabrication. Strong focus on construction and how materials relate to concept. Enrollment is limited to 12. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,800. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ART
title: Painting Basics
description: An introduction to basic painting issues, stressing a beginning command of the conventions of pictorial space and the language of color. Class assignments and individual projects explore technical, conceptual, and historical issues central to the language of painting. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,800. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ART
title: Introduction to Digital Photog...
description: Exploration of the transition of photographic processes and techniques into digital formats. A range of tools are presented including scanning, digital cameras, retouching, color correction, basic composition, and inkjet printing. Students produce original work throughout the technical component of the class. After mastering the basics, students work toward the completion of a final project, and the focus of the remaining classes is on critiques. Throughout the term, lectures and presentations raise critical issues concerning the impact of digital applications and by-products on the medium of photography. Students must have access to a digital camera and bring it to class. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,800. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ART
title: Cinematic Storytelling in Prague
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Intensive, hands-on exploration of film history, theory and practice, offered in partnership with FAMU, the national film and television academy of the Czech Republic, Europe's top film school. Theory, tools, and techniques and practical skills--from operating a 16mm film camera to recording dialogue to lighting a set--which students will apply in the production of a weekly film project. During the third week of the program, students will travel to the beautiful spa town of Karlovy Vary (Carlsbad) to attend the world-renowned Karlovy Vary International Film Festival. Instructors for the program will include Pavel Jech, the dean of FAMU, and Michal Bregant, the Director of the National Film Archive of the Czech Republic. The program includes a two-week mini course in Czech language and culture. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited to 16. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Yale Credit: Tuition: $3,600. 1 FAMU Credit: Tuition $3,750. Tuition is $7,350 total. Course dates: May 31 - June 27.

subject: ART
title: Introduction to Interactive De...
description: A studio introduction to typographic communication and design on the internet. Students will conceive, design, and build a series of websites as well as engage in class discussions and critiques. The relationships between web server, web browser, content author, graphic designer, and user will be explored as both technical issues and aesthetic opportunities. Sustainability and evolution of a website over time is emphasized. HTML, CSS, image preparation, and basics of JavaScript will be taught utilizing the computer facilities at the Yale School of Art. No previous knowledge necessary. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,800. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ART
title: Principles of Animation
description: Introduction to the principals, history, and practice of animation in visual art and film. With a primary focus on production, this course utilizes historical and theoretical developments in 20th- and 21st-century animation as a framework for making digital animation. Production focuses primarily on digital stop-animation and compositing, as well as 2D and 3D computer-generated animation. Students gain an understanding of the principals of animation and develop fundamental skill-sets in Apple Final Cut Pro, Adobe After Effects, and Autodesk Maya 2012. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,800. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ASTR
title: Galaxies and the Universe
description: A nontechnical introduction to stellar populations and the structure and evolution of the Milky Way galaxy; external galaxies, radio galaxies, and quasars; cosmology and the expanding universe. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of elementary algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: BIOL
title: Biochemistry, Biophysics, and...
description: Introduction to the study of life at the molecular level and to cell biology and membrane physiology. Topics include the three-dimensional structures and function of large biological molecules, the human genome, the design of antiviral drugs to treat HIV/AIDS, organization and functional properties of biological membranes, membrane physiology and signaling, rough endoplasmic reticulum and synthesis of membrane/secretory membrane proteins, endocytosis, the cytoskeleton, and cell division. Covers the material of BIOL 101 and 102, the first half of the yearlong introductory biology sequence. Followed in the summer by BIOL S106. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: BIOL
title: Genes, Ecology, and Evolutiona...
description: Introduction to genes, genetics, developmental biology, ecology, evolutionary biology, animal behavior, and the history of life. How genes control development and disease; Mendel's rules; examples of organ physiology; evolutionary transitions and natural selection; adaptation at genic, chromosomal, cellular, organismal, and supra-organismal levels; distributional and social consequences of particular suites of organismal adaptations. Covers the material of BIOL 103 and 104, the second half of the yearlong introductory biology sequence. Prerequisite: BIOL 101 and 102 or BIOL S105. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: BIS
title: Accelerated Biostatistics
description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides a comprehensive introduction to the use of statistics in the fields of epidemiology, public health, and clinical research. Students gain experience conducting and interpreting a broad range of statistical analyses. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability distributions, parameter estimation, hypothesis testing, sampling, analysis of variance, nonparametric tests, and linear regression. Through weekly computer laboratory sessions, students become familiar with the SAS statistical software package.
For students in the Advanced Professional M.P.H. program; not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.

subject: BRST
title: London & Modernity: ca 1880 to...
long_title: London & Modernity: ca 1880 to the Present
description: This course explores modernity in relation to the changing character of London as a metropolitan and imperial center from the late 19th century to the present day. "Modernity" is a highly contested term. In this course it is used to denote both the attempts to modernize the city itself, as well as its inhabitants' experiences of the ambiguities of life in the biggest city the world has ever known. How London coped (or failed to cope) with the social and environmental problems created by its enormous size is one of the early questions explored in the course. Other key themes are: the local and the global, sexual scandal, popular entertainment, consumer culture, the experience of war, and the development of a multi-racial society. The fashion, food and popular music of London emerge as important components of the city's global identity in the 20th century. Students will come to see today's London as a complex product of development and destruction, viewing it more as historians than mere tourists.

subject: BRST
title: Victorian Fiction
description: A selection of Victorian texts offering a broad view of period life and culture. Emphasis on novels that show "outsiders" adjusting to the complexities of urban and rural life in nineteenth-century England. Study of the orphan, alien, disoriented, or alienated characters who find a place in society through art, intellectual enterprise, or spiritual enlightenment.

subject: BRST
title: Modern British Drama
description: A detailed study of representative works of modern British drama, based on current productions on the London stage. Theatrical conventions developed by playwrights and actors in the theater of postwar Britain, both on the fringe and in the mainstream of the West End. Attention to social issues addressed by the plays.

subject: CDE
title: Accelerated Social and Behavio...
long_title: Accelerated Social and Behavioral Foundations of Health
description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides students with an introduction to social and behavioral science issues that influence patterns of health and health care delivery. The focus is on the integration of biomedical, social, psychological, and behavioral factors that must be taken into consideration when public health initiatives are developed and implemented. This course emphasizes the integration of research from the social and behavioral sciences with epidemiology and biomedical sciences.
Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.

subject: CDE
title: Accelerated Epidemiology
description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides a comprehensive overview of epidemiologic concepts and methods. Topics include measurements of disease frequency and association, study design (including randomized and non-randomized controlled trials, cohort studies, case-control studies, cross-sectional studies, and ecologic studies), screening principles, reliability and validity, bias, confounding, and effect modification. After completing this course, students are able to calculate and interpret epidemiologic parameters, identify the strengths and weaknesses of various study designs, and apply the principles and methods of epidemiology to the design and analysis of new studies.
Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.

subject: CGSC
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity, punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit Tuition 3,600. Technology fee $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 and Session B July 6 - August 7.

subject: CGSC
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity, punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit Tuition 3,600. Technology fee $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 and Session B July 6 - August 7.

subject: CGSC
title: Mental Lives of Babies and Ani...
long_title: Mental Lives of Babies and Animals
description: Offered Online. Interdisciplinary exploration of the cognitive, social, and emotional capacities of creatures lacking language and culture. The extent to which our complex psychology is unique to mature humans; the relative richness of a mental life without language or culture. Some attention to particular human populations such as children with autism and adults with language disorders. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN 30275) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN 30277).

subject: CGSC
title: Mental Lives of Babies and Ani...
long_title: Mental Lives of Babies and Animals
description: Offered Online. Interdisciplinary exploration of the cognitive, social, and emotional capacities of creatures lacking language and culture. The extent to which our complex psychology is unique to mature humans; the relative richness of a mental life without language or culture. Some attention to particular human populations such as children with autism and adults with language disorders. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN 30275) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN 30277).

subject: CHEM
title: Chemistry in Context
description: Chemistry studied in the context of major contemporary issues, such as climate change, environmental degradation, renewable energy, and pharmaceutical developments. This course takes an interactive approach to learning chemistry with demonstrations and hands-on experience. Activities will highlight chemical reactions in fuel cells, properties of acid rain, nylon production, radioactivity, and more. Does not satisfy premedical chemistry requirements or requirements for the Chemistry major. Not open to students who have completed another chemistry course at Yale. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: CHEM
title: ComprehensiveGeneralChemistry
description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive inorganic and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Session A: stoichiometry, atomic structure, chemical bonding, molecular structure, gas laws, properties of solutions. These courses (CHEM S114/S115), with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: CHEM
title: Comprehensive General Chemistry
description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive inorganic and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Session B: chemical kinetics and thermodynamics, chemical equilibria, acid-base theory, electrochemistry, transition metal chemistry, introduction to organic chemistry. These courses (CHEM S114/S115), with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: CHEM
title: Organic Chemistry
description: The fundamental principles of organic chemistry. Session A: structure and bonding, chemical energetics, stereochemistry, alkanes, nucleophilic substitution, infrared spectroscopy, alkenes and alkynes, alcohols and ethers. These courses (CHEM S220/S221), with laboratories, satisfy departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. For college students only. After college level general chemistry. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: CHEM
title: Organic Chemistry
description: The fundamental principles of organic chemistry. Session B: aldehydes and ketones, strategies in organic synthesis, carboxylic acid derivatives, carbonyl condensation reactions, sulfur and phosphorus compounds, bifunctional molecules, carbohydrates, organic nitrogen compounds, amino acids and proteins. These courses (CHEM S220/S221), with laboratories, satisfy departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. For college students only. After college level general chemistry. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: CHEM
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Introductory laboratory course covering basic synthetic and analytic techniques in organic chemistry. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S220 or subsequently. For college students only. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses (CHEM S222/S223) must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,800. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: CHEM
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Introductory laboratory course covering basic synthetic and analytic techniques in organic chemistry. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S221 or subsequently. For college students only. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses (CHEM S222/S223)must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,800. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: CHLD
title: Autism and Related Disorders
description: Offered Online. Survey of current understandings and treatment of autism from infancy through adulthood. Topics include etiology, diagnosis and assessment, treatment and advocacy, and social neuroscience methods. Focus on ways in which research findings are integrated into diagnosis and treatment practices. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: CLCV
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: CZEC
title: In Prague Film and Fiction
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, and language. Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak (Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnost Lustig. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students choose either FILM or CZEC credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 28 - August 2.

subject: DIR
title: A Practical Approach to Direct...
description: Designed to introduce practical tools for directing, this course applies to anyone who is interested in working on technique as a director, whether as a career, for teachers directing a school play or for community theater productions. Topics include dramaturgy, script analysis, the director's work with the script, working with the actor, voice and speech techniques, and stage management organization. No formal training in directing necessary. Applicants should send a brief statement describing their background and areas of interest. A transcript is not required. Limited housing is available for this course; contact Yale Summer Session at 203.432.2430 for details. Tuition $750. Students must be available from 9:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday through Friday as well as Saturday afternoons and evenings and Sunday morning and afternoon. This intense course requires a full commitment of the student's time. The faculty reserves the right to add, extend, or adjust scheduled hours to accommodate the progress of the class. Course not open to pre-college students. Dates: July 16 - 25.

subject: DRMA
title: Yale Summer Conservatory for A...
description: Exploration and development of the fundamentals of the actor's craft based on the principles of Stanislavski. The course is actually a concise training program in which each student takes more than one class. The classes are in the following areas: (1) play analysis class, to understand what is to be acted; (2) acting class, to learn the application of basic acting techniques; (3) vocal production class, to improve vocal and articulation skills; (4) improvisation and mask class, to help free the imagination and to build confidence in spontaneous self-expression; (5) movement class, to strengthen the body and to encourage the use of the body for emotional expression; and (6) scene study class, to understand how the classes listed above come together when working on a scene. The instructors constitute a teaching staff of working professionals and are assisted by teaching associates giving the students individual attention. The summer drama program requires a full commitment of the student's time. Classes are held in the mornings, afternoons, and two evenings each week, Monday through Friday, with 26 to 28 classroom hours each week, 4 to 6 library hours each week, plus additional hours for individual tutorials and scheduled rehearsal time. Extra evening and Saturday morning sessions may be scheduled for group activities and additional classes. A single grade will be awarded for the course. Enrollment is limited. Complete applications must include a resume of relevant experience and a letter of recommendation from a drama teacher or other theater professional. Application deadline: May 1. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: E&EB
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. The structure and function of the human body, organization of body systems, and the study of regional anatomy. Modern body imaging methods. Fundamental dissection methods. Students will perform a complete dissection of a human cadaver. Meets departmental requirements for the major and is appropriate for students seeking to fulfill health profession prerequisites. Prerequisite: BIOL 101, 102, 103, and 104 or an equivalent or an equivalent full-year introduction to biology sequence. For college students and beyond. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Lab fee $600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: E&EB
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Lecture, field, and laboratory based course that will explore the biodiversity-rich aquatic habitats of the Central Highlands (Appalachians, Ozark and Ouachita Mountains). Topics include the taxonomic diversity, ecology, biogeography, and evolutionary biology of aquatic animals (insects, crayfishes, mussels, and fishes). The course will include a two week field trip in the middle of the summer session to observe and sample riverine habitats in Tennessee, Kentucky, and Alabama. Prerequisite: BIOL 104 or equivalent. Recommended preparation: E&EB 225. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Course fee: $300. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Finance
description: Introduction to modern theories of decision-making under uncertainty by investors in financial markets. Analysis of expected utility theory and the Allais paradox, subjective expected utility and the Ellsberg paradox, portfolio theory, effcient markets, APT and behavioral economics. Prerequisites: ECON 115 and MATH 115 or their equivalents or scores of 5 on both AP Microeconomics and AP BC Calculus. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Microeconomics
description: Same as Econ S115

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Microeconomics
description: Same as Econ S115

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
description: An introduction to basic macroeconomic concepts and theories, such as national income accounting, theories of growth, inflation, unemployment, business cycles, fiscal and monetary policy, banking, finance, and economic crises, with special emphasis on the recent financial crisis. Prerequisite: ECON 108, 110, 115 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30035) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30036).

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
description: An introduction to basic macroeconomic concepts and theories, such as national income accounting, theories of growth, inflation, unemployment, business cycles, fiscal and monetary policy, banking, finance, and economic crises, with special emphasis on the recent financial crisis. Prerequisite: ECON 108, 110, 115 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30035) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30036).

subject: ECON
title: Econometrics and Data Analysis I
description: Offered Online. Basic probability theory, statistics, and linear regression. Methods of evaluation quantitative information; the use of data to answer quantitative questions in the social sciences. After ECON S115 and MATH 112 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30150) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30151).

subject: ECON
title: Econometrics and Data Analysis I
description: Offered Online. Basic probability theory, statistics, and linear regression. Methods of evaluation quantitative information; the use of data to answer quantitative questions in the social sciences. After ECON S115 and MATH 112 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30150) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30151).

subject: ECON
title: Game Theory
description: An introduction to the theory of multiperson decision problems and its application in economic analysis. Discussion of static and dynamic noncooperative games with particular attention to the notions of Nash equilibrium and sub-game perfect equilibrium. Prerequisite: two terms of introductory economics (ECON 115 and 116 or the equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ECON
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Offered Online. An introduction to the theory of multiperson decision problems and its application in economic analysis. Discussion of static and dynamic noncooperative games with particular attention to the notions of Nash equilibrium and sub-game perfect equilibrium. Prerequisite: two terms of introductory economics (ECON 115 and 116 or the equivalent). For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ECON
title: Game Theory
description: Offered Online. An introduction to the theory of multiperson decision problems and its application in economic analysis. Discussion of static and dynamic noncooperative games with particular attention to the notions of Nash equilibrium and sub-game perfect equilibrium. Prerequisite: two terms of introductory economics (ECON 115 and 116 or the equivalent). For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to the Chinese Ec...
description: Offered in Beijing, China. This course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities' Global Summer Program. An overview of the Chinese economy, with attention to its rapid growth in the past two decades and its current challenges. The cultural and political background of the economy, China's market transition, manufacturing and financial sectors, foreign trade, foreign direct investment and technology transfer, and the reform of state-owned enterprises. Prerequisite: introductory economics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Beijing, costs of room and board in Beijing, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Course dates: July 4 - August 2.

subject: ECON
title: Public Economics
description: The role of government in the economy and in our economic lives. Reasons for government intervention in the market economy and the impact of government expenditure programs and taxation systems on welfare and behavior. Tools of microeconomics applied to issues such as government response to global warming, the impact of redistribution and social insurance on individual behavior, school choice, social security vs. private retirement savings accounts, and government vs. private health insurance. Prerequisite: ECON S115 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ECON
title: Private Law and Contract Enfor...
long_title: Private Law and Contract Enforcement in the United States and France
description: Offered in Paris, France. Parties engaging in economic exchange often organize their relationships through contracts and other private legal structures. The organization of exchange and the body of law and private institutions that govern and influence its structure. Substantive theoretical component and practical component, with on-site modules at the International Court of Commercial Arbitration in Paris. A comparative legal and institutional approach will be maintained throughout. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: MATH 112, ECON 121, or permission of instructor. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition: $7,000. Course Dates: June 29 - July 31.

subject: ECON
title: Causes&ConsequencesCorruption
description: Offered Online. Corruption, a manifestation of the principal-agent problem, is an obstacle to economic efficiency. This course examines the economic, cultural, and political causes and consequences of corruption; cross-country comparisons of corruption levels; and examples of successful reforms and policies to combat corruption in bureaucracy and business. Students will complete a documented research project as part of the course. For college students and beyond. Prerequisite: ECON 108, 110, or 115, or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ECON
title: Welfare Economics and Equality
description: This is a course on efficiency,i.e., the First and Second Welfare Theorems, in simple general equilibrium models of competitive markets and market failures, where the welfare theorems do not hold, that is, externalities, public goods and monopoly pricing. In particular, we consider and compare the relative merits of the Kaldor-Hicks compensation principle in partial equilibrium analysis and the Pareto principle in general equilibrium analysis. Prerequisites: ECON 121 and MATH 112. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ECON
title: Topics in International Econom...
description: Recent developments in international economics. Trade policy and market structure; the economics of trading blocs such as the EU and NAFTA; the economic consequences of continued U.S. external deficits; globalization and inequality; exchange rates, interest rates, and volatility; speculative capital flows and exchange rate policies; and financial crises and the prospects for the European Monetary Union. Prerequisites: Statistics or equivalents. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: EDST
title: Childhood and Adolescence in t...
long_title: Childhood and Adolescence in the Twentieth Century
description: Examines how the nature of childhood has transformed from the early twentieth century to today. Key developments in the creation of modern childhood and adolescence including child labor, educational practices, children as consumer, and the emergence of the notion of the teenager. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: EENG
title: The Digital Information Age
description: An introduction to information transmission and storage and their impact on society. Technological issues and trade-offs that affect the design of digital systems. Elementary circuits and computer logic; sensors and actuators; signal processing and design for data transmission; information transmission on the World Wide Web. Projects include analysis and design using Matlab or Excel. Intended for students in the humanities and social sciences and for freshmen considering a major in electrical engineering. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ENAS
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ENAS
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ENAS
title: Introduction to Computing for...
long_title: Introduction to Computing for Engineers & Scientists
description: An introduction to the MATLAB and C programming languages for solving a variety of problems encountered in engineering, mathematics, and the natural sciences. General programming techniques, data analysis, numerical simulations, and transmission of data files between programs. Projects include processing microphone speech and digital images. prerequisites: MATH 115 or equivalent. Recommended preparation: previous programming experience. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ENAS
title: Ordinary and Partial Different...
long_title: Ordinary and Partial Differential Equations with Applications
description: Basic theory of ordinary and partial differential equations useful in applications. First- and second-order equations, separation of variables, power series solutions, Fourier series, Laplace transforms. Prerequisites: ENAS 151 or equivalent and knowledge of matrix-based operations. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ENGL
title: Writing Seminars I
description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 12. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30039) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30040).

subject: ENGL
title: Writing Seminars I
description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 12. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30039) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30040).

subject: ENGL
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Reading and Writing the Modern Essay
description: Cancelled. Close study of selected works of nonfiction prepares students to become critical readers and to apply professional strategies to their own writing. Readings from such authors as Joan Didion, Malcolm Gladwell, Maxine Hong Kingston, N. Scott Momaday, George Orwell, Brent Staples, Jonathan Swift, Henry David Thoreau, Tom Wolfe, and Alice Walker. Written assignments, involving frequent revision, include autobiography, portraiture, nature writing, cultural critique, and formal argument. Students who have not completed an introductory college-level writing course should take ENGL S114 instead. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ENGL
title: Major English Poets
description: An introduction to the diversity and the continuity of the English language tradition through close reading of four poets from the fourteenth through the seventeenth centuries, Chaucer, Spenser, Shakespeare, and Donne. Emphasis on developing skills of literary interpretation and critical writing. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ENGL
title: Readings in American Literature
description: An introduction to as well as an exploration of American literature from the nineteenth century to the present. We will ask many questions of these texts, not the least of which is "what do we mean when we say 'American?'" Given the wide range of the body of work that comprises American literature, however, we will also periodically ask in passing what we mean by "literature," so as to consider what roles the literary plays in creating and shaping the possibilities of social imagination, private and public discourse, as well as one's own identity. Emphasis on analytical reading, critical writing, and class discussions. Authors include Melville, Poe, Hawthorne, Whitman, Dickinson, Barnes, Toomer, H. Crane, W. C. Williams, L. Hughes, and M. Robinson. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ENGL
title: Introduction to Writing Fictio...
long_title: Introduction to Writing Fiction and Creative Nonfiction
description: Conducted as a workshop, this course offers students the opportunity to write fiction and the particular sort of nonfiction that reflects and explores the narrative of their own lives. The focus will be on elements common to all storytelling, among them, character, narrative development, voice, and clarity of language and thought. Students may concentrate on a single genre, or, if they wish, experiment with both. Readings will include selections from contemporary American fiction and creative nonfiction. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be submitted with the online application. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ENGL
title: Shakespeare: Comedies and Roma...
description: A study of ten comedies and romances, their festivities and their reservations. Extensive practice in writing critical essays. Students should come to the first class having read A Midsummer Night’s Dream. (The Signet edition is preferred.) Selections from filmed productions of the plays are screened semiweekly, and students are asked to attend a number of these screenings. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ENGL
title: Shakespeare: Histories and Tra...
description: Study of three histories and seven tragedies at the pinnacle of Shakespeare's career. Focus on the source of each play's pathos and the nature of its poetic sublimity; some attention to performance and to the relation between the genres of history and tragedy. Extensive practice in writing short and medium-length critical essays. Students should come to the first class having read Julius Caesar. (The Signet edition, ordered through The Yale Bookstore, is preferred, but the Norton genre volumes are especially handsome substitutions; the Arden single play editions are more than acceptable if their price is not intimidating.) The regular course meetings will be supplemented by six evening screenings, and students are asked to attend at least four of these. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ENGL
title: Milton
description: Offered Online. This course is a study of Miltonâs major poetry. We will attend to the poetâs relation to the social and political struggles of the seventeenth century, and we will look in addition at his influence on literature and thought today. Our main texts are Miltonâs Paradise Lost and Samson Agonistes, and we conclude the term with a consideration of Philip Pullmanâs deeply Miltonic science fiction trilogy His Dark Materials. Students will watch or listen to pre-recorded lectures, and will meet online for biweekly seminar discussions. Satisfies pre-1800 requirement. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ENGL
title: From Gutenberg to Google Books...
long_title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
description: The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the hand-press book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mechanized printing and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar through a series of firsthand encounters with manuscripts, rare books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ENGL
title: Travel Writing
description: Offered in Auvillar, France. Examines travel writing, surveying a wide range of works, from long-form place essays to destination articles, from travel memoir to adventure odysseys. Readings include, Paul Theroux, Ryszard Kapuscinski, Jan Morris, and Pico Iyer. How voyages lend travel writers structure: a natural beginning, middle, and end. Students are encouraged to take advantage of their geographic mobility for their assignments and tasked to find an innovative mode or vehicle of exploring their chosen place. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: July 17 - August 14.

subject: ENGL
title: British Literature of the 1960s
description: An examination of British novels, drama, and poetry of the 1960s. Selected authors include Spakr, Beckett, Stoppard, Larkin, Plath, and Hill. Relevant selections of music, films, and television programs are also included. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ENGL
title: Modern American Drama
description: Offered Online. In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ENGL
title: Theater Now
description: Study of drama, performance, and dance-theater created in the last ten years, with special attention to works produced in 2014 and 2015. Readings from both published and unpublished American and British plays, contemporary criticism, interviews, and essays by the artists themselves. Video of works created by companies such as Elevator Repair Service, Les Freres Corbusier, and the Nature Theater of Oklahoma. Will include attendance of productions in and around New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: ENGL
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. An examination of creative and analytic responses to the changes in daily life brought about by the rapid proliferation of digital media and forms of communication. Both utopian and dystopian visions of digital society will be considered. Works to include nonfiction by Marshall McLuhan, Jaron Lanier, Clay Shirky, and Evgeny Morozov; fiction by Russell Hoban and Dave Eggers; and films such as 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Social Network, The Internship, and Her. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ENGL
title: Investigative Journalism
description: Techniques of in-depth reporting, ranging from interviews and document research to journalistic storytelling; the evolution of "muckraking" in the United States; and the ethical, philosophical, and political issues raised by such work. Improvement of the students' practical research and narrative skills through weekly assignments and a term-long writing project. Designed equally for those with journalistic experience and for those with skills in other arenas. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ENGL
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Reviewing Film, Theater, Music, and Dance
description: Cancelled. An advanced workshop for writers who want to review the performing arts for newspapers, magazines and other media. Weekly assignments to review screenings and performances, many of which will be part of New Haven’s International Festival of Arts and Ideas. Class trip to New York City to review a theatre production. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: EP&E
title: Lies and Deception
description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: EP&E
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: EP&E
title: Ethnic Conflict
description: Causes of ethnic conflict and its most violent forms, including ethnic civil war. Critically reviews the dominant explanations of ethnic conflict and applies them to actual cases, including current examples of ethnic war, to arrive at an in-depth understanding of the problem and consider some of its solutions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: ER&M
title: U.S. Border and Immigration Po...
description: U.S. border and immigration policies at the national, state, and local levels from the colonial period to the present. The historical evolution of border and immigration policy; contemporary debates; the effects of shifting policy on immigrants of varying legal statuses. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: EVST
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: EVST
title: Global Energy Strategies
description: Explores the energy problems that will face the international community in the coming decades and the prospects for sustainable solutions. Emphasizes the importance of developing strategies to deal with the world's future energy supply and considers the challenges of limited natural resources and a growing world population. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: EVST
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. The development of international environmental policy and the functioning of global environmental governance. Critical evaluation of theoretical claims in the literature and the reasoning of policy makers. Introduction of analytical and theoretical tools used to assess environmental problems. Case studies emphasize climate, forestry, and fisheries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: EVST
title: Gender, Justice, and the Envir...
description: Focus on relationships between gendered beings (both human and non-human) and the environments in which they live. Topics include feminist theories of nature and materiality, bodies and environmental toxicities, interspecies connections, and the sociopolitical contexts of environmental disasters. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: F&ES
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. The development of international environmental policy and the functioning of global environmental governance. Critical evaluation of theoretical claims in the literature and the reasoning of policy makers. Introduction of analytical and theoretical tools used to assess environmental problems. Case studies emphasize climate, forestry, and fisheries. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: FILM
title: In Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film...
long_title: In Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film and Fiction
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, and language. Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak(Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnos Lustig. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students choose either FILM or CZEC credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 28 - August 2.

subject: FILM
title: Cinematic Storytelling in Prague
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Intensive, hands-on exploration of film history, theory and practice, offered in partnership with FAMU, the national film and television academy of the Czech Republic, Europe's top film school. Theory, tools, and techniques and practical skills--ÃÂÃÂfrom operating a 16mm film camera to recording dialogue to lighting a set--which students will apply in the production of a weekly film project. During the third week of the program, students will travel to the beautiful spa town of Karlovy Vary (Carlsbad) to attend the world-renowned Karlovy Vary International Film Festival. Instructors for the program will include Pavel Jech, the dean of FAMU, and Michal Bregant, the Director of the National Film Archive of the Czech Republic. The program includes a two-week mini course in Czech language and culture. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited to 16. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Yale Credit: Tuition: $3,600. 1 FAMU Credit: Tuition $3,750. Tuition is $7,350 total. Course dates: May 31 - June 27.

subject: FILM
title: Paris and the Cinema
description: Offered in Paris, France. Introduction to French cinema and culture from 1915 to the present which focuses on the mystery, romance, youth and consumerism of Paris. Explores Parisian neighborhoods on city walks and visits two preeminent French cinema institutions (the Cinémathèque Française and the Institut Lumière). Films will include Breathless, La Haine, and Amélie. All readings will be in English with further optional readings in French. All films are subtitled in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Course dates: July 4 - August 8.

subject: FILM
title: The Blockbuster and the Bomb
description: Exploration of the contemporary Hollywood film industry. Introduction to the close analysis of film sequences. Central components of a Hollywood production, such as script, director, star, and genre. Aspects of the industry, including production, distribution, and exhibition. Ingredients of blockbuster success; why some films fail catastrophically. Case studies pair current films with historical ones. Includes two screenings per week. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: FILM
title: Sports and Media
description: A study of the interrelations among popular sport, cinema, television, radio, print, and social media. Explores topics of identity, commerce, and civics through contemporary texts (Hunger Games, Senna, Invictus), and introduces the history of sport in media culture. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: FILM
title: Japanese Cinema and Culture
description: Offered in Tokyo, Japan. A broad introduction to Japanese cinema and its interrelations with modern Japanese culture. Surveys the history of Japanese film from the silent era, through the golden ages of the 1930s and the 1950s, up until the present, with particular emphasis on recent decades and films that students can relate to the Japan they experience on the streets. Readings in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Tokyo, costs of room and board in Tokyo, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 27 - August 1.

subject: FILM
title: Filmmaking: The Anatomy of a S...
long_title: Filmmaking: The Anatomy of a Scene
description: The basic building block of a movie is a well-crafted scene. It instructs the screenwriter/filmmaker in a visceral and tangible way as to what does and does not work in production.This class focuses on the anatomy of a motion picture scene using the tools, craft, technical, and creative methods required to translate the written word to a visual language. Students learn filmmaking -- script analysis for production preparation: producing, budgeting scheduling, camera aesthetics and techniques, directing, working with actors, lighting, sound design, editing and media management. The course is a comprehensive collaborative journey using material previously produced and critically recognized in order to allow students to explore the contribution of the producer, director, cinematographer, sound designer, and editor. The emphasis is as much on process as product. Each student works collaboratively on multiple scenes over the course of the semester in each of the above mentioned crew positions. The pace of the course assumes some prior technical familiarity with digital HD cameras, field sound recording, competency with HD workflow and final cut non-linear editing: however, the course begins with detailed seminars in each of the crew positions before productions begin. The goal of the class is to go through a practical professional procedure of creating scenes from the perspective of key crew positions as if it were a complete motion picture, thus enabling the students to understand, absorb and solve their own work. Limited to 16 students. 2 Credits. Tuition: $7,000. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: FILM
title: Money and Media: The Business...
long_title: Money and Media: The Business of Hollywood
description: An examination of the key events and ideas that shape the modern motion picture business from financial, institutional, and historical standpoints. Topics include ways that the business has evolved in response to changes in technology, distribution, and competition; how the business dictates what ends up on screen; and relationships among studios, actors, agents, independent filmmakers, distributors, and the viewing audience. Industry practitioners discuss special topics. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: FILM
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Eighteen films depicting some of the varied effects of war, especially the two World Wars, on individual combatants, civilians, occupied peoples and others not engaged in military action itself. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: FILM
title: Film, Video, and American Hist...
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include American films from a broad range of time periods and genres. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: FILM
title: Visual Approaches to Global He...
description: Offered in Swaziland. Explores the intersection of global health and visual media. Focuses on global health issues such as HIV, TB, human rights, and violence in public health. Students learn filmmaking as a means for translating complex public health concepts into a format approachable by a general audience and create a short film on a selected global health topic. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Swaziland, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 20 - August 2.

subject: FILM
title: Screenwriting
description: A seminar and workshop in screenplay writing. Students learn the basics of the craft by reading existing scripts, looking at films from a writer's perspective, and writing a short screenplay. Additional hours of individual screenings required. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: FILM
title: Television and Crime
description: Examines crime dramas, reality television, news coverage, and crime documentaries. Analysis of how popular media shapes public views on criminality, law enforcement, violence, due process, and judicial responsibility. Pays attention to the historical relationship between media, crime, and the politics of race, class, gender, and sexuality. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: FREN
title: Elementary and Intermediate Fr...
description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for students with no previous study of French.
