Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 4.

subject: LITR
title: Psychological Disciplines and...
description: From the promise of beauty to the experience of literary seduction, the class will address the complex function and effects of the aesthetical regime. What constitutes the experience in the arts? And what separates our desires in the real world from the pleasures art promises us? Is there really a fundamental difference between low or even sexual desires and those higher forms that art can provide us with? And is it true that dreaming is as close to suppression and wish fulfillment as film is said to be?Apart from theoretical texts (including Freud, Jung, Fechner) class will treat painting (from Raffaello to Dali), photography (from Man Ray to Jeanloup Sieff) and literature (from Rousseau to Doeblin), as well as opera and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: LITR
title: The Logic of Dreams
description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud'sÂ Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: LITR
title: The Problem of Evil
description: Examines the problem of evil in three major literary texts from the Renaissance to our own time: Milton's Paradise Lost, Shelley's Frankenstein, Rushdie's Satanic Verses. How the idea of an omniscient, benevolent God can coexist with the presence of suffering in the world; whether evil exists or whether it is an aspect of human behavior and choice; and what can we do to train ourselves to combat evil and suffering. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: MATH
title: Calculus of Functions of One V...
long_title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable I
description: Limits, continuity, differentiation of elementary and transcendental functions, applications. No prior acquaintance with calculus is assumed. Pre-college students should enroll in this course only if they have a strong foundation in algebra and pre-calculus. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: MATH
title: Calculus of Functions of One V...
long_title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable II
description: A continuation of MATH 112. The definite integral, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration, polar coordinates, Taylor series, applications. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: MATH
title: Mathematical Models in the Bio...
long_title: Mathematical Models in the Biosciences I: Calculus Techniques
description: Introduction to topics in mathematical modeling that are applicable to biological systems. Discrete and continuous models of population, neural, and cardiac dynamics. Stability of fixed points and limit cycles of differential equations. Applications include Norton's chemotherapy scheduling and stochastic models of tumor suppressor gene networks. Prerequisite MATH S112 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Functions of S...
long_title: Introduction to Functions of Several Variables
description: Calculus of functions of several variables, with some linear algebra. Intended for students in the social sciences, especially those majoring in Economics. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). Yale students may not take this course after MATH 120 or 222. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: MATH
title: Calculus of Functions of Sever...
long_title: Calculus of Functions of Several Variables
description: Analytic geometry in three dimensions, using vectors. Real-valued functions of two and three variables, partial derivatives, gradient and directional derivatives, level curves and surfaces, maxima and minima. Parametrized curves in space, motion in space, line integrals; applications. After MATH 115 or with permission of instructor. May not be taken after MATH 121. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: MCDB
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Introductory survey of multidisciplinary approaches to studying the neurobiology of memory. Current conception of memory mechanisms and contributions of the fields of molecular and cell biology, psychology, neuroscience, genetics, and physics will be discussed. Some previous coursework in Biology is required. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: MCDB
title: Laboratory for Principles of M...
long_title: Laboratory for Principles of Molecular, Cell, and Developmental Biology
description: Experimental techniques and procedures in molecular and cell biology. Must be taken after BIOL 101 and BIOL 102, or after BIOL S105. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,800. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: MCDB
title: How the Brain Works
description: For non-science majors. The biology of the brain as it relates to various functions and dysfunctions. Gross anatomy and cellular composition of nervous system tissue; development of the nervous system, including its organization into motor, sensory, and other systems; the biology underlying complex processes such as learning, memory, and mood regulation; psychoactive and performance-enhancing drugs in the brain; disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease, autism, and depression. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A; June 1 - July 3.

subject: MCDB
title: Cell Biology
description: A comprehensive course in cell and molecular biology.  Emphasis on general principles of cell function and rationale and design of pertinent biomedical experiments. Prerequisite: BIOL 101 and BIOL 102, or BIOL S105, or permission of the instructor. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: MCDB
title: Neurobiology
description: Introduction to neuroscience, divided into 3 course modules: 1) Cellular neurophysiology, addressing the excitable properties of neurons and the function of synapses, 2) Systems neurobiology, examining neural circuits as they relate to the functional properties of the nervous system, with each system that is addressed examined in detail, and 3) Neural development and plasticity, examining the cellular and molecular mechanisms governing neural development, plasticity, and the establishment of memory. Prerequisites: introductory course in biology (BIOL 101-104) and at least 1 semester of college chemistry, or permission of instructor. A course in physics or its equivalent is also recommended but not required. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: MMES
title: Introduction to Islam
description: Topics include Muhammad and the Qur'an; Muslim tradition and religious law; Islamic philosophy and theology; Shi'ism and Sufism; basic beliefs and practices of the Muslim community; religious institutions; and modern trends. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: MMES
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Politics, Identity, and Culture in Israel: 1948-Present
description: Cancelled. Introduction to contemporary culture and representations of Israeli society and politics. Focus on the elements that make up Israeli identity. Themes include the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, personal and collective identity formation, gender, Palestinian Israelis, Arab-Jews (Jews of North African origin), Zionism and post-Zionism. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: MMES
title: Society and Politics of North...
long_title: Society and Politics of North Africa
description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. Overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and have the option of home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 27-August 1.

subject: MUSI
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Practical investigation of the basic principles of tonal harmony and counterpoint, phrase structure, and form through exercises in thoroughbass, analysis, part-writing, and model composition. Emphasis on styles and forms of the Classical period: Bach, Mozart, and Haydn. Fluency in music fundamentals, key signatures, time signatures, intervals, scales, and chords is expected. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: MUSI
title: Brains of Genius: Mozart & Fri...
description: Offered Online. The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Einstein. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: MUSI
title: CANCELLED
long_title: An Introduction to German Lieder: History and Performance
description: Cancelled. The extraordinary song repertoire of nineteenth-century Germany will be explored from multiple perspectives (historical context, literary tradition, aesthetic style) through multi-disciplinary modalities (performance, literary analysis and critical listening). Beyond readings, presentations and discussion, participants will have opportunities to experience masterpieces of the German Lied as performers, whether singing alone or as part of an ensemble. Designed for performers and non-performers alike. German- and music-reading ability not required. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: MUSI
title: Jazz and Race in America
description: Offered Online. A study of the evolution of jazz, from its precursors in the music of Africa through its beginnings in New Orleans to its fusion with rock in the 1970s. Jazz's greatest artists and their styles are presented with selected music of each jazz period and a discussion of the racial and sociological factors surrounding the genre's development. While no extensive music theory background or formal instrumental experience is required, students who can read music will be best prepared to fulfill the listening and form identification assignments. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: MUSI
title: Electronic Dance Music: Histor...
description: Offered Online. A developmental history of technology in music creativity, with particular focus on electronic dance music and the aesthetics and characteristics of selected genres such as house, techno, trance, dub step, jungle, and drum 'n' bass, among others. Includes an introduction to the fundamentals of musical notation - meter, rhythm, scales, keys, melodies, and chords - as expressed in these genres. EDM portfolio exercises both in Musescore and Ableton Live Intro. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: NELC
title: Buried Cities: Thera, Pompeii,...
description: Introduction to the art and archaeology of three Mediterranean sites buried by volcanic eruptions, with special attention to new discoveries and interpretations. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: NELC
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Politics, Identity and Culture in Israel: 1948-Present
description: Cancelled. Introduction to contemporary culture and representations of Israeli society and politics. Focus on the elements that make up Israeli identity. Themes include the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, personal and collective identity formation, gender, Palestinian Israelis, Arab-Jews (Jews of North African origin), Zionism and post-Zionism. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: NHTL
title: Intensive Nahuatl Language and...
description: An intensive immersion course designed to familiarize students with modern and colonia Nahuatl. Beginning-, intermediate-, and advanced-level students may apply. Formal class hours are complemented with individual practice sessions and group cultural activities. Partial scholarships are available. Details on the Yale Latin American Iberian Studies website, http://www.yale.edu/macmillan/lais/summer.html. Open to undergraduate and graduate students. 3 Credits. Tuition $5,000. Program dates: June 29 - August 7.

subject: NURS
title: Community Health Nursing and P...
long_title: Community Health Nursing and Public Health
description: 4 credit hours. This course explores the multidisciplinary theoretical foundations that are the basis for community health nursing practice. Community health nurses provide preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitation, and hospice services across the life span. The clinical experience focuses on the delivery of these health services in community organizations. A community-as-partner assessment and diagnosis project, which culminates in identification of a community health problem and potential solutions, augments core seminar content. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Clinical Practice in Maternal-...
description: 2 credit hours. This course focuses on clinical practice essential to nursing care of women, newborns, and their families throughout the childbearing cycle and the neonatal period. Clinical settings include hospital and ambulatory care. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Seminar in Maternal-Newborn Nu...
description: 2 credit hours. This course presents theory essential to the provision of nursing care to childbearing families throughout the childbearing cycle, the neonatal period, and the pre- and inter-conceptional phases. Application of the nursing process as it relates to the promotion, maintenance, and restoration of health is emphasized. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Clinical Practice in Pediatric...
description: 2 credit hours. Utilizing a family-centered approach, this course provides clinical experience in identifying and assessing children's physiological and developmental needs, and planning, implementing, and evaluating a plan of nursing care to meet the needs of a particular child and his/her family in health care settings. Students have opportunities to use principles of growth and development, knowledge of the child's and family's physical and emotional responses to illness, and principles of pediatric nursing in caring for children and their families. The student gains skill and knowledge in the nursing role and an appreciation for the importance of utilizing research findings in practice and collaborating with other health professionals. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Seminar in Pediatric Nursing
description: 2 credit hours. This course presents theory essential to promote health and adaptation to illness for children and their families. Emphasis is placed on growth and development, as well as pathophysiological, social, environmental, and cultural factors that influence children's and families' response to health and illness. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Master's Independent Study: Pl...
long_title: Master's Independent Study: Plant Based Health
description: This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.

subject: NURS
title: Master's Independent Study: Pl...
long_title: Master's Independent Study: Plant Based Health
description: This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.

subject: NURS
title: Primary Care of Children II
description:
2 credit hours per term. This course provides clinical experience in advanced pediatric primary care and management, including work with complex families. The student provides health care for children over the course of the year in the Primary Care Center, Yale-New Haven Hospital, and at selected pediatric primary care sites in the community. Required of pediatric nurse practitioner students in the final year of specialization. Five hours weekly in a clinical setting and fourteen hours of clinical conference per term.
Prerequisite: successful completion of 632a/b.

subject: NURS
title: Thry & Applctn of Proj Mgmt
description: 1.5 credit hours. This course provides an overview of theoretical principles and concepts essential to assessing, designing, implementing, and evaluating population-based health projects within and across the health system and other organizations. In this course, students critically examine change, decision making, evaluation, and management-related theories as a foundation for project planning, implementation, and evaluation of an evidence-based improvement project. Students identify and develop a theory-based project derived from an integrated synthesis of the literature. Students also identify appropriate software, tools, and communication techniques essential for leading an interprofessional team from inception to completion of the project within and across health care systems or other organizations. The tools and processes learned in this course will support work toward the subsequent capstone experience. Taught as an intensive during the summer intersession. Required of D.N.P. students in the first year.

subject: NURS
title: Achieving Population Health Eq...
description: 2 credit hours. This course provides a critical overview of the historical and contemporary health and health disparities research, relevant literature, and policies as essential context for understanding how to achieve health equity. The social and biological determinants of health and health disparities are also critically examined in light of social, political, economic, cultural, legal, and ethical issues. Selected health and health disparities population-based data are examined as a foundation for explicating how subpopulations experience disparate health across the life span. Students examine how past and current policies (state, federal, tribal), politics, population-based data findings, and selected frameworks enhance or act as barriers to achieving health equity with diverse populations, systems, and/or communities. Students also design an organizational policy plan for achieving health equity within a health system, organization, and/or community-based health system. Required of D.N.P. students in the second year.

subject: NURS
title: Capstone Seminar
description: 2 credit hours. This course is designed to help students integrate D.N.P. course content and practica into a final capstone proposal. Students work in concert with their assigned capstone adviser during the spring term of their first year in the development of a draft proposal. During this course, draft proposals are reviewed using the Guidelines for Developing and Implementing a Capstone, with the addition of rubrics for evaluation of the work. The student presents his or her proposal for critique by peers, capstone adviser, and faculty of record during the last seminar session during the summer intensive. Required of D.N.P. students.

subject: PHIL
title: Happiness
description: Historical and analytical inquiry into the meanings of happiness and their change over time. How new approaches to this topic in the social and natural sciences both complement and challenge time-honored philosophical and religious ideas. Whether happiness is a subjective and/or culturally relative idea. Whether happiness should be a goal in life. The relationship of happiness to other valued goods such as meaning, freedom, pleasure, virtue, and justice. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Philosophy
description: Introduction to the history and methods of philosophical reflection and inquiry. Exploration of several perennial philosophical issues and the distinctive ways of addressing these issues through a close reading of historical texts and group discussion. Readings include selections from the works of Plato, Aristotle, Hume, Kant, Mill, and twentieth-century philosophers. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PHIL
title: First-Order Logic
description: An introduction to formal logic. Study of the formal deductive systems and semantics for both propositional and predicate logic. Some discussion of metatheory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PHIL
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30160) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30162).

subject: PHIL
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30160) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30162).

subject: PHIL
title: International Ethics
description: Overview of central ethical questions that arise at the international level. Topics include global governance, just war, human rights, humanitarian intervention, immigration, and climate change. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PHIL
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Introduction to Eastern philosophy through the study of philosophical and religious texts. Topics include reality and illusion, knowledge, self, right and wrong, nonattachment, meditation, aesthetics, the meaning of life, and death. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PHIL
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. A survey of contemporary issues in the philosophy of mind, including arguments for and against materialism and accounts of intentional states, qualitative states, and mental causation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PHIL
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PHIL
title: Lies and Deception
description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PHYS
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PHYS
title: Movie Physics
description: Offered Online. A critical evaluation of Hollywood action movies, using the laws of physics and Fermi-type estimation techniques to distinguish between fictional and real movie physics. For college students and beyond; intended for non-STEM majors. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PHYS
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics Laboratory
description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S180, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students only. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,800. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics Laboratory
description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S171 or PHYS S181, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students only. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,800. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics for the Lif...
long_title: University Physics for the Life Sciences
description: An introduction to classical physics with special emphasis on applications drawn from the life sciences and medicine. Topics include electricity and magnetism, circuits, light and optics, sound, and modern physics. Essential calculus is introduced as needed. Prerequisite: PHYS 170 or PHYS 180. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics
description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers Newtonian mechanics, gravitation, waves, and thermodynamics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151, 170, 171. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics
description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers electromagnetism, optics, special relativity, and quantum physics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151, 170, 171. Prerequisite: PHYS 180 or equivalent. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PLSC
title: Introduction to Political Phil...
description: Issues of liberty, equality, and justice considered from within the Western tradition of political philosophy. Readings from Plato, Aristotle, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, Mill, and contemporary authors. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PLSC
title: The Moral Foundations of Polit...
description: Open to Yale students and students from the International Alliance of Research Universities (IARU) Global Summer Program. Two students from each partner university, including Yale, will be admitted to this course. Partial funding is provided for all students enrolled. An introduction to contemporary perspectives on foundational normative issues of political life. Provides an introduction to the core first-order normative questions of political morality as we might argue about them today. Students are expected to have read "Justice as Fairness: A Restatement" by John Rawls prior to the first day of class. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PLSC
title: The Balance of Power: Theory a...
long_title: The Balance of Power: Theory and Practice
description: Explores the evolution of the international balance of power since the outset of the twentieth century. The causes and conduct of World Wars I and II and the Cold War, as well as the evolution of international politics since the demise of the Soviet Union. Emphasis is both analytic and historical. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PLSC
title: Introduction to Human Rights T...
long_title: Introduction to Human Rights Theory and Practice
description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PLSC
title: Foreign Policy and Internation...
description: The mutual influence of law and politics at the international level. Topics include the sources of international law, the participants, courts, dispute settlement, jurisdiction, and customary law. Readings on foreign policy making, international law, treaties, and international courts from the literature of United Nations bodies and of the International Law Commission. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PLSC
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. The development of international environmental policy and the functioning of global environmental governance. Critical evaluation of theoretical claims in the literature and the reasoning of policy makers. Introduction of analytical and theoretical tools used to assess environmental problems. Case studies emphasize climate, forestry, and fisheries. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PLSC
title: International Human Rights and...
description: International human rights bodies and their implications for international politics. The role of human rights institutions in affording remedies to victims of state abuse. The emergence and exercise of international human rights law, including its nature, mechanisms, and logic. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PLSC
title: The Cold War
description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PLSC
title: International Ethics
description: Overview of central ethical questions that arise at the international level. Topics include global governance, just war, human rights, humanitarian intervention, immigration, and climate change. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PLSC
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. This course will view presidential campaigns as a window to gain a wider and richer understanding of American political history. Readings will include some of the classics of campaign reporting, as well as reportage about the people and ideas that go into the making of political history. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PLSC
title: Crime and Punishment
description: Topics in the history, theory, and realities of crime and punishment in the contemporary United States. Focus on various theories of criminal process in light of empirical evidence, the politicization of crime, civil rights issues, psychiatry and the law, abortion, and arguments about prison reform. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PLSC
title: Reading the Constitution
description: Offered Online. Intensive introduction to the written Constitution, revolving tightly around two books authored by the instructor--America's Constitution: A Biography (2005) and America's Unwritten Constitution: The Precedents and Principles We Live By (2012). Provides detailed knowledge of America's written Constitution and considers various techniques of constitutional interpretation. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PLSC
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PLSC
title: Lies and Deception
description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PLSC
title: Ethnic Conflict
description: Causes of ethnic conflict and its most violent forms, including ethnic civil war. Critically reviews the dominant explanations of ethnic conflict and applies them to actual cases, including current examples of ethnic war, to arrive at an in-depth understanding of the problem and consider some of its solutions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PLSC
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Politics, Identity, and Culture in Israel: 1948-Present
description: Cancelled. Introduction to contemporary culture and representations of Israeli society and politics. Focus on the elements that make up Israeli identity. Themes include the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, personal and collective identity formation, gender, Palestinian Israelis, Arab-Jews (Jews of North African origin), Zionism and post-Zionism. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PLSC
title: War and Constitutions
description: Examines the historical record from ancient times to the present to understand how wars have shaped the nation state, including structures of accountability and political rights. Provides students with the analytical and empirical tools for understanding the effects of war on constitutional structures across time and place. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PLSC
title: The Politics of Nationalism an...
long_title: The Politics of Nationalism and Ethnicity
description: Study of contemporary work on ethnicity and nationalism from multiple disciplines and analytic traditions. Factors that make ethnicity and nationalism distinctive among social bases of political mobilization. Critical examination of the theory that nationalism is an exclusively modern phenomenon. Nationalism as an attempt to tie powerful organizations to specific territories and individual loyalties. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PORT
title: Elementary Portuguese for Spea...
long_title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages I
description: First three weeks of the course in New Haven, one week in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. An intensive elementary course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S120 and PORT S352. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: May 31 - July 25.

subject: PORT
title: Elementary Portuguese II
description: First three weeks of the course in New Haven, one week in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. An intensive elementary course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S110 and PORT S352. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: May 31 - July 25.

subject: PORT
title: Intermediate Portuguese
description: First four weeks in SÃ£o Jose do Rio Preto, SÃ£o Paulo, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. Conducted in Portuguese. An intensive intermediate course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills.Includes visiting the city of SÃ£o Paulo and the state of Minas Gerais to provide a broader perspective of modern Brazil. Immersion in the language with exposure and active participation in diverse activities such as visits to industries, trade schools, after school activities, lectures, and historic tours. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S140. Prerequisite: PORT 120, 122, 125 or equivalent. Credit only on completion of PORT S140. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Course dates: May 31 - July 25.

subject: PORT
title: Intermediate Portuguese
description: First four weeks in Sao Jose do Rio Preto, Sao Paulo, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. Conducted in Portuguese. An intensive intermediate course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Includes visiting the city of Sao Paulo and the state of Minas Gerais to provide a broader perspective of modern Brazil. Immersion in the language with exposure and active participation in diverse activities such as visits to industries, trade schools, after school activities, lectures, and historic tours. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S130. Prerequisite: PORT 120 or equivalent. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Course dates: May 31 - July 25.

subject: PORT
title: Introduction to Brazil
description: First three weeks of the course in New Haven, one week in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. Conducted in English with sessions in Portuguese. An introduction to Brazilian cultural history from 1500 to the present. Essential themes and figures for understanding modern Brazil. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S110/S120. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition: See PORT S110/S120 for tuition. Course dates: May 31-July 25.

subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Psychology
description: Offered Online. A survey of major psychological approaches to the biological, cognitive, social, and emotional bases of behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PSYC
title: Human Emotion
description: Introduction to major discoveries and theories of human emotion. Evolutionary theories of the origins of emotion; culture, sex and gender influences; emotion and morality; brain basis of emotion; sleeping and feeling; relationship between emotion and thinking; love and relationships; development of emotion; animal vs. human emotion; abnormal emotions in mental illness; and happiness. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PSYC
title: Social Psychology
description: Introduction to the theories, methodologies, and applications of social psychology. Topics include attitudes and persuasion, self and identity, group interactions, social norms, prosocial behavior, aggression, and interpersonal attraction. Study of how the presence of others, real or imagined, influences our thoughts, behaviors, and feelings. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PSYC
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30159) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30161).

subject: PSYC
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30159) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30161).

subject: PSYC
title: Drugs, Brain, and Behavior
description: Offered Online. Introduction to the scientific study of psychoactive drugs (i.e., drugs that affect the mind). Drug use in modern society and the basic neurobiology related to neurotransmission and drug effects. Pharmacological and neurobiological mechanisms of different classes of legal, illegal, and medicinal drugs, including alcohol, caffeine, tobacco, stimulants, depressants, anti-depressants, pain-killers, and hallucinogens. Common misconceptions, drug effects, addiction, medical use of marijuana, and America's drug policies. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: PSYC
title: Sex, Evolution, and Human Nature
description: Offered Online. How natural selection works and how it can be applied to the study of human psychology. Attention to research methods and findings. Topics include sex and mating, alliances, kinship, visual attention, spatial cognition and memory, and social exchange. May not be taken for credit after PSYC 171. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PSYC
title: Abnormal Psychology
description: Study of the major forms of psychopathology that appear in childhood and adult life. Topics include the symptoms of mental disorders; the etiology of disorders from a variety of perspectives (psychological, biological, and sociocultural); and issues pertaining to diagnosis and treatment. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: PSYC
title: Mental Lives of Babies and Ani...
long_title: Mental Lives of Babies and Animals
description: Offered Online. Interdisciplinary exploration of the cognitive, social, and emotional capacities of creatures lacking language and culture. The extent to which our complex psychology is unique to mature humans; the relative richness of a mental life without language or culture. Some attention to particular human populations such as children with autism and adults with language disorders. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN 30168) and Session B July 6 - August 7 (CRN 30276).

subject: PSYC
title: Mental Lives of Babies and Ani...
long_title: Mental Lives of Babies and Animals
description: Offered Online. Interdisciplinary exploration of the cognitive, social, and emotional capacities of creatures lacking language and culture. The extent to which our complex psychology is unique to mature humans; the relative richness of a mental life without language or culture. Some attention to particular human populations such as children with autism and adults with language disorders. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN 30168) and Session B July 6 - August 7 (CRN 30276).

subject: PSYC
title: Autism and Related Disorders
description: Offered Online. Survey of current understandings and treatment of autism from infancy through adulthood. Topics include etiology, diagnosis and assessment, treatment and advocacy, and social neuroscience methods. Focus on ways in which research findings are integrated into diagnosis and treatment practices. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: RLST
title: Introduction to Islam
description: Topics include Muhammad and the Qur'an; Muslim tradition and religious law; Islamic philosophy and theology; Shi'ism and Sufism; basic beliefs and practices of the Muslim community; religious institutions; and modern trends. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: RLST
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. The Old Testament/Hebrew Bible as an expression of the religious life and thought of ancient Israel and a foundational document of Western civilization. Emphasis on the texts' historical and cultural setting in the ancient Near East. Introduction to a wide range of critical and literary approaches to Biblical study. Close reading of selected passages, with discussion of their history of interpretation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: RLST
title: From Crusade to Enlightnement:...
long_title: From Crusade to Enlightnement: Medieval & Early Modern Europe
description: A survey of Western Europe from the late medieval period to the eighteenth century. Major topics include the Crusades, late medieval heretical movements, the Protestant and Catholic Reformations, the wars of religion, the seventeenth-century witch craze, and the rise of secularism and tolerance. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: RLST
title: Media and Religion
description: Examines relationship between media and religion, and our position relative to both. Readings are diverse (temporally and geographically), but focus on four forms of media: paper/writing, screens/scenes, soundscapes, and the dis/embodied. Topics include: diaries, calligraphy, greeting cards, scrapbooks, films, Hollywood celebrities, evangelical revivals, spirit photos, foot-binding, prisons, radio shows, and websites. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian II
description:
Continuation of RUSS 150.

1.5 Yale College course credits

subject: RUSS
title: Second-Year Russian I
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 120. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S140 & RUSS S242. Credit only on completion of RUSS S140. For more information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.

subject: RUSS
title: Second-Year Russian II
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 130. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S140 & RUSS S242. For more information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.

subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian I
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the third year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 140. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S151 & RUSS S242. For more information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.

subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian II
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg.An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the third year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 150. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S150 & RUSS S242. For more information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.

subject: RUSS
title: Fourth-Year Russian I
description: Five weeks in St. Petersburg (no language classes in New Haven). An intensive "language-abroad" course featuring study of Russian at the fourth year level. Students stay with a Russian family and receive language training (7 hours per week), further developing all four language skills and immediately putting them to practice during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 151. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 24 - July 31.

subject: RUSS
title: Russian Culture
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. Explores the cultural history of the imperial Russian capital, founded by Peter the Great in the early eighteenth century as a window on Europe. Considers the semiotics of Petersburg through a careful reading of selected literary texts, both prose and poetry, including Pushkin, Gogol, Dostoevsky, Blok, Bely, Gumilev, Akhmatova, Mandelstam, Khlebnikov, Mayakovsky, Kharms, and others, as well as some works of literary and cultural criticism. The classroom sessions are complimented with a rich selection of excursions and tours in and around St.Petersburg. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with either RUSS 130/140 or RUSS S150/151. For more information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition: see RUSS S130/140 or RUSS S150/151. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.

subject: SCIE
title: Scientific Research: Process a...
description: This course is intended to provide comprehensive training and support to STARS students engaged in scientific research. Students will be introduced to the scientific process, including hypothesis testing, experimental design and data interpretation, through lectures, reading and discussions of the primary scientific literature. Skills development will emphasize the process of discussions of preparing written scientific reports and oral presentations highlighting effectual communication skills and the ability to interpret and display quantitative and qualitative information. For STARS students only. Course may not be repeated for credit. 1 credit. Tuition: $3,600. May 31 - July 31.

subject: SOCY
title: Global Public Health
description: Introduction to public health issues and health development processes that are independent of national territorial boundaries but also incorporate the health needs and priorities of individual nation states. Mechanisms and challenges involved in incorporating the World Health Organization's commitment to primary health care with principles that currently dominate the global public health agenda. Sociological critique of public health interventions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: SOCY
title: Multiculturalism and the Order...
description: Is there a link between social identity and crime? What is the relationship among race, gender, and perceptions of criminality? What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime, and criminal justice policy? This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime, and the criminal justice system. Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice. Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: SOCY
title: Society and Politics of North...
long_title: Society and Politics of North Africa
description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. Overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and have the option of home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 27-August 1.

subject: SOCY
title: Culture of Southeastern Europe
description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with HIST S299. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,500. Course dates: June 28 - August 1.

subject: SPAN
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. For students who wish to begin study of the Spanish language. Development of basic skills in understanding, speaking, reading, and writing through a functional approach to the teaching of spanish grammar. Includes an introduction to the cultures (traditions, art, literature, music) of the Spanish-speaking world. Audio-visual materials are incorporated into class sessions. Conducted in Spanish. To be followed by SPAN S120. Credit only on completion of SPAN S120. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: SPAN
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Class sessions incorporate short authentic texts in Spanish, audiovisual materials, and film. Cultural topics of the Spanish-speaking world (traditions, art, literature, music) are included. Conducted in Spanish. After SPAN S110 or in accordance with placement results. Admits to SPAN 130 or 145. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish I
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Lima (CRN: 30242), Bilbao (CRN: 30241), or Quito (CRN: 30243). Development of proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and videos; presentation of cultural topics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S140 (in Lima CRN: 30247, in Bilbao CRN: 30248, in Quito CRN: 30249), and either S247 (CRN: 30172) in Lima, S248 (CRN: 30173) in Bilbao, or S249 (CRN: 30174) in Quito. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Credit only on completion of SPAN S140. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: May 31 - July 25.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish I
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Lima (CRN: 30242), Bilbao (CRN: 30241), or Quito (CRN: 30243). subject: SPAN
title: Cultural Studies of Peru
description: 4 weeks in New Haven and 4 weeks in Lima, Peru. The historical, social, and cultural development of Peru from pre-Columbian times to the present. Peruvian history; the culture and character of Peru and of its capital, Lima; architecture, art, gastronomic history, immigration, and ethnicity. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, music, and visual arts. Conducted in Spanish. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Peru, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Must be taken concurrently with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: see SPAN S130/S140. Course dates: May 31 - July 25.

subject: SPAN
title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: Hi...
long_title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture
description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Bilbao. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Classes will be held in the headquarters of the University of Deusto, located opposite the statuary and facing the Guggenheim Museum. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: see SPAN S130/S140. Course dates: May 31 - July 25.

subject: SPAN
title: Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Tim...
long_title: Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Times to Present
description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Quito. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Ecuador from Pre-Columbian times to the present. Presented through a variety of materials (literary texts, essays, films, music, visual arts). Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Quito, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/S140. Course dates: May 31 - July 25.

subject: STAT
title: Introduction to Statistics
description: An introduction to statistical reasoning. Topics include controlled experiments and observational studies; histograms and scatterplots, averages and standard deviations; measurement error, the normal approximation; correlation and regression; probability and chance variation; sampling, the Gallup Poll and Current Population Survey; tests of significance. Focus on understanding concepts rather than mathematical manipulation. No formal mathematical prerequisite. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: STCY
title: Introduction to the Study of t...
long_title: Introduction to the Study of the City
description: An examination of forces shaping American cities and strategies for dealing with them. Topics include housing, commercial development, parks, zoning, urban renewal, landmark preservation, new towns, and suburbs. Includes games, simulated problems, fieldwork, lectures, and discussion as well as field trips in New Haven and to New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili I
description: Offered in Tanzania. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S140. Credit only on completion of SWAH S140. Prerequisite: SWAH 120 (Elementary Kiswahili II) or equivalent. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Kenya. Students are responsible for arranging travel and paying for airfare to and from Mombasa, as well as passport, visa, inoculations, and similar expenses. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad webiste. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,500. Course dates: May 31 - July 26.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili II
description: Offered in Tanzania. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S130. Prerequisite: SWAH 130 (Intermediate Kiswahili I) or equivalent. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Kenya. Students are responsible for arranging travel and paying for airfare to and from Mombasa, as well as passport, visa, inoculations, and similar expenses. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad webiste. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,500. Course dates: May 31 - July 26.

subject: SWAH
title: Advanced Kiswahili: Advanced S...
description: Offered in Tanzania. Development of fluency through readings and discussions on contemporary topics in Kiswahili, including its origins and spread to different parts of Eastern and Central Africa. The role of Kiswahili in addressing issues such as health and the environment. Introduction to literary criticism in Kiswahili. Materials include Kiswahili oral literature, prose, poetry, and plays, as well as texts drawn from popular and political culture. Prerequisite: SWAH 140 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Kenya, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,000. Course dates: May 31 - July 12.

subject: THST
title: Theater Now
description: Study of drama, performance, and dance-theater created in the last ten years, with special attention to works produced in 2014 and 2015. Readings from both published and unpublished American and British plays, contemporary criticism, interviews, and essays by the artists themselves. Video of works created by companies such as Elevator Repair Service, Les Freres Corbusier, and the Nature Theater of Oklahoma. Will include attendance of productions in and around New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: THST
title: British Literature of the 1960s
description: An examination of British novels, drama, and poetry of the 1960s. Selected authors include Spakr, Beckett, Stoppard, Larkin, Plath, and Hill. Relevant selections of music, films, and television programs are also included. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: THST
title: Modern American Drama
description: Offered Online. In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.

subject: WGSS
title: Women, Food and Culture
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the gendering of food production, preparation, and consumption in cross-cultural perspective. Topics include agricultural practices, cooking, pasteurization, kitchen technology, food storage, home economics, hunger, anorexia, breast-feeding, meals, and ethnic identity. Class visits to Peabody Museum, Beinecke Library, Yale Farm and Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.

subject: WGSS
title: Gender, Justice, and the Envir...
description: Focus on relationships between gendered beings (both human and non-human) and the environments in which they live. Topics include feminist theories of nature and materiality, bodies and environmental toxicities, interspecies connections, and the sociopolitical contexts of environmental disasters. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
